From what I knew just three months ago, I’m seeing remarkable development.

I wouldn’t have believed it if someone told me a few months ago that I’d be composing and notating a 2-minute solo piece. Three months ago, I was having difficulty reading music scores, using software like Sibelius, and understanding some musical concepts.   My tutor told me that it was normal and that I should expect a learning curve, but I had not anticipated making such rapid progress in such a short period of time.

I learned a lot about scales and, in particular, how melodies are made. I had a lot of fun analyzing everything from simple ancient melodies to more complicated and contemporary ones, which helped me with my Assignment 2 composition.

About Assignment 2

The assignment took far longer than I thought once again. According to the OCA assignment introduction, this should take about 3 hours, yet it took me about 3 days. Despite the amount of time it took me, I am quite pleased with the outcome. I was able to incorporate my idea for this work into the score, generating two contrasting parts for the two clarinet registers – chalumeau and clarion.

The four basic elements of music are rhythm, melody, harmony, and tone colour (Copland, Rich and Slatkin, 2011). Because this section of the course is about melody, I concentrated on the melodic rather than the rhythmic aspects of the piece. I wanted at least one memorable section of the tune that the listener would recognize immediately when it was repeated. With the main motif, I believe I was successful.

Although I liked creating for untuned percussion, I must say that composing for a pitched instrument was far more enjoyable. However, I must admit that the rhythm aspect was crucial, particularly in terms of not being stuck with a time signature or employing pauses as rhythmic alterations.

On the downside, I believe I could improve some aspects of my composition. I think the music sometimes goes to predictable places rather than surprising the listener with unexpected notes. In the next assignment, I must avoid this. I also believe I rushed several parts of the composition when the music needed to rest. Due to the 2-minute time limit, this was necessary.

Overall, I’m looking forward to hearing what my tutor thinks of this work and any ideas and adjustments he or she may have.

References

Copland, A., Rich, A. and Slatkin, L., 2011. What to listen for in music. New York, N.Y: Signet Classic.

item.content:encoded:
As part of the second assignment, I had to write a composition for a solo woodwind instrument that lasted between 1:30 and 2 minutes. The challenge of this composition is that I can use whichever scale I choose (it can be more than one scale), to take advantage of the instrument’s specific features and to respect its range.

You can find the final score here and listen to it below:

Just like in the first assignment, I thought it was beneficial to create an outline and get an idea of what I was trying to accomplish beforehand. Though it may seem counterproductive at first, the structure and the idea helped me stay focused and keep a coherent thought process.

The Idea / Theme

This piece will centre around a character that is mournful during the workweek and eccentric on the weekend. In a routine and boring job, weekdays become monotonous and boring, while weekends become exciting and fun.

Usually on Mondays you feel melancholy, Tuesday through Thursday are monotonous and regretful, followed by Friday and Saturday with euphoria, and finally Sunday turns slowly into melancholy again and you’re back on Monday.

The Structure

As soon as I had the idea, the structure made sense to me. First, there is an intro, followed by the main theme, and then there is a happy section. Revert to the main motif before ending the same way it began.

For the first two parts, the tempo would be slow, followed by a fast tempo for the third part, and then slowly decreasing for the final two parts.

The Motifs

My process for composing a motif was to play simple lines on the piano and to find one that sounds right to me. Inspiration overcame transpiration in this case. After some time, I began playing these four notes.

In spite of the simplicity of the melody, I liked the quaver/crochet rhythm, which gave me a sense of lull and monotony that I felt was appropriate for the B part. Although it feels like it is going up, it lacks the strength to stay up and goes down. Likewise, our character longs for the energy to accomplish something but returns to mourning.

After that, I discovered that the scale I wanted to work on would be the E harmonic minor, with the seventh diminished, which sounds exotic but at the same time lamenting.

The A part of the song has a similar motif to the B part, but to me, it feels more nostalgic, like someone is remembering the good old days (like the weekend).

Because the C part is festive, I knew right away that I needed to change the scale, but not by much because the character remains the same and I didn’t want to have a big contrast. I chose to use the Ukrainian minor scale in the key of C, which is one of the most widely used scales in Klezmer music. As I worked with this scale, I realized these are exactly the notes of the G harmonic minor scale. I found this scale very festive even though it is a minor scale, which goes against the common idea that minor scales are sad.

In the C part of the song, the motif is made up of quavers and semiquavers, enjoying the wonderful staccato the clarinet can produce.

The Clarinet

The clarinet is extremely versatile, and that’s why I chose it. With this piece, I wanted to push myself to explore both low and high registers while maintaining a cohesive line throughout. Clarinets have the broadest range of all woodwinds and can easily transition from pianissimo to fortissimo (Adler, 2002).

My research on the clarinet led me to these videos from Josh Plotner which explain, among other things, that the composer should avoid the Throat Tones register (from G4 to Bb4) due to its hollowness and weak sound. Although I tried to avoid these notes, it was difficult for me to eliminate them from the melody.

In the videos, it is also explained to avoid flutter tongue and use growl instead, since it sounds better.

Part I—Essential Writing for Clarinet
Part II—Advanced Writing for Clarinet

This document from the Young Music Makers of Dyfed offers some techniques for the clarinet, one of which caught my attention, which is breathing into the clarinet without playing any notes.

It is also advised to avoid the transition between B4 and Bb4, referred to as “the break,” due to its difficult transition that only experienced players can handle (Adler, 2002).

The Composition

Part A Bars 1-9

This section serves as a brief introduction and presents the first motif. The purpose of this section is to show the listener that the melody will stay in the Chalumeau register.

  • Bars 1-4 are slow notes establishing the scale
  • Bars 5-9 are the part A motif followed by a descending to end this part

Part B Bars 10-19

While the tempo remains the same, the time signature switches to 3/4 here, and the dynamics increase. As a result, the listener can feel the character’s discomfort and lament.

  • Bars 10-11 the main motif is presented and raised by one step
  • Bars 12-13 a variation of the motif going down and ending in the 5th
  • Bar 14 is a variation of the main motif
  • Bar 15 is a repetition of bar 11
  • Bar 16 is similar to bar 11 but with the extra QUAVER
  • Bars 17-19 the melody descends ending with a trill to the tonic

Part C Bars 20-43

In contrast to the previous two, this is the fastest section. Here, glissandos and growls are used to convey the feel of the parties and the exuberance of the weekend concept.

  • Bar 20 is a scale run ascending over two octaves
  • Bar 21-22 a glissando sustained and played fortissimo
  • Bars 23-24 a crescendo in dynamics and offbeat notes
  • Bars 25-27 is the part C motif and its variations
  • Bar 28 the triplets are descending
  • Bars 29-30 are another variation of the motif
  • Bars 31-32 is the repetition of the same note in the semiquaver/quaver rhythm, ending in a flutter tongue in the highest E
  • Bars 33-34 are a variation of the motif
  • Bars 35-39 the quavers are used with the staccato
  • Bars 40-43 are a descending of crochets with quavers in between

Part B’ Bars 44-51

The B part is shortened here, leading the listener slowly from the party of the C section to the end. Dynamic returns to piano.

  • Bars 44-47 return to the harmonic scale and to the crochet/quaver rhtyhm
  • Bars 48-51 are the main motif with a few variations

Part A’ Bars 52-58

While this section is slower than the previous one, it is similar to the introduction, ending in the same note as it began, giving it the appearance of being forever looped.

  • Bars 52-55 are similar to bars 5-7 but in a 3/4 time signature
  • Bar 56 is made entirely of crochets
  • Bars 57-58 a little pause to breathe into the instrument and realising the final two notes

References

Adler, S., 2002. The study of orchestration. 3rd ed. New York: W.W. Norton.

2019. Writing for the Clarinet. [pdf] Available at: <https://ymmd.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Writing-for-the-Clarinet-.pdf> [Accessed 14 September 2021].
